video.title: React / GraphQL Course - Build a social media app (MERNG Stack)
video.description:
Learn how to create a social media app using MongoDB, Express, Node, React, GraphQL, and Node (the MERNG stack). You will learn how to implement a GraphQL server that uses Node and Express to communicate to a MongoDB Database and fetch and persist data to a social media app back-end.

⌨️ Source Code: https://github.com/hidjou/classsed-graphql-mern-apollo/tree/master

✏️ This course was created by Classsed. Check out their channel: https://www.youtube.com/c/classsed
🔗 Classsed on Patreon: https://www.patreon.com/classsed

⭐️ Course Contents ⭐️
⌨️ (0:00:00) Intro & app demo
⌨️ (0:02:47) GraphQL explained + tech used 
⌨️ (0:07:56) Server demonstration
⌨️ (0:13:21) Setting Up Database & Server
⌨️ (0:39:43) Register & Login Users
⌨️ (1:12:50) Authentication middleware & Create/Delete posts
⌨️ (1:35:02) Finishing up the server
⌨️ (2:07:58) Client start & Apollo setup
⌨️ (2:17:45) Semantic UI & Routes
⌨️ (2:34:08) Displaying posts
⌨️ (2:51:56) Login & Register pages
⌨️ (3:19:31) Authentication Context
⌨️ (3:46:57) Adding posts
⌨️ (4:07:51) Like Button
⌨️ (4:27:13) Single post page
⌨️ (4:55:52) Displaying, Adding & Deleting Comments
⌨️ (5:15:27) Info Popups
⌨️ (5:26:06) Deployment to Heroku & Netlify

⭐️ Special thanks to our Champion supporters! ⭐️ 
🏆 Loc Do
🏆 Joseph C
🏆 DeezMaster

--

Learn to code for free and get a developer job: https://www.freecodecamp.org

Read hundreds of articles on programming: https://freecodecamp.org/news

replies.author: Powdee
replies.text:
My friend, the reason I think you are getting this error is because you are using

 const post = await post.findById(postId); INSTEAD OF
 const post = await Post.findById(postId);

You need to use capital "P" post because that is the reference to the mongodb data base, not lower case p because that has no reference to db.

Thanks

replies.author: Ezequiel Castellanos
replies.text: @Lewis Casewell thanks bro! you saved me

replies.author: Lewis Casewell
replies.text:
In your AuthRoute.js
import { useContext } from "react"
import { Navigate } from "react-router-dom"
import { AuthContext } from "../../context/auth"

function AuthRoute({ children }) {
  const { user } = useContext(AuthContext)
  return user ? <Navigate to="/" /> : children
}

export default AuthRoute;

In App.js

<BrowserRouter>
          <MenuBar />
          <Routes>
            <Route path="/" element={<Home />} />
            <Route
              path="login"
              element={
                <AuthRoute>
                  <Login />
                </AuthRoute>
              }
            />
            <Route
              path="register"
              element={
                <AuthRoute>
                  <Register />
                </AuthRoute>
              }
            />
          </Routes>
        </BrowserRouter>

replies.author: Cornstar23
replies.text:
I think this has to do with how the Apollo client uses the data returned back from the mutation. If you look in the typeDefs.js, notice how deleteComment returns a Post:
deleteComment(postId: ID!, commentId: ID!): Post! 
Apollo client takes that post data and updates its cache for that post, which then updates the page. However, if you look at the definition of deletePost, you'll see:
deletePost(postId: ID!): String!
It just returns a string saying that it was successful. Therefore, the Apollo client does not update its cache for all of the posts, and you have to do it manually like in the video.

topLevelComment.author: hellosugaree
topLevelComment.text:
You are amazing. I'm working on a career transition from scientist to software engineer. I spent the last few months learning all of the parts in isolation: javascript, html, css, react, node, express, mongo, etc. While I feel like I was making great progress and able to use each part individually, I was really struggling to connect everything to bring the entire stack together into something meaningful. Then I discovered this video...

The first hour was probably the hardest part, but about 3/4 of the way through building the server, I feel like a lightbulb went off in my head. From that point on, I found myself often jumping ahead of the video and writing new features and crossing into brand new territory before watching those parts of the video. Then I would go back and watch the video to see how you solved it versus how I solved it. A few examples of many that I solved on my own were adding the create post functionality, adding authorization header to the httplink, hooking up the like button, and manually writing new posts to the query cache, and adding robust error handling on the client side for all form submissions.

I feel like I'm in a dream right now, because I can't believe what I just built and the amount of progress I've made in such a short time. I'm now able to read and understand the package documentation to deploy new features. 

I can't thank you enough for putting this together.

replies.text: not sure if this is your issue, but starting at around 5:12:30 he addresses this error.  On the backend in the typeDef for the createComment mutation he erroneously specified the postId as type String! instead of ID!. Not really sure why he didn't change it on the backend to ID (he mentions something about people who are just doing the React bit getting confused).   I changed it on the backend to ID and was still getting the 400 error if I tried to create a comment on a post that was already created prior to making the change.  I created a new post after the change and was able to make a comment on it without the problem.  I don't really understand this behavior but there it is.

topLevelComment.author: Afeef Rb
topLevelComment.text:
For anyone who keeps getting *Application Error* . If your _heroku logs_ has the error: *Can't find module "./config.js"* . Then you need to comment out the *require("./config")* in all instances where it was required. Then go to your Heroku app settings, add under Config Vars your MONGODB and SECRET_KEY. Then:

git add .
git commit -m "some msg"
git push -u origin master (or main branch) => _Update your git repo_
git push heroku master (or main branch) => _Update your heroku repo & deploy_

replies.author: Buy Shark
replies.text: it`s a bad practice coz if we have one component at 10 level depth that need user , every component from app.js to tha component should just pass this object somehow - a lot of useless acts that leads to the bugs. that`s why we use context api or redux or mobx : we have one state and every component at every level in depth could have a piece of that state without drilling every component in the chain

replies.author: Tobskii
replies.text:
Hi! Responding in case someone else is wondering the same thing.

This is from the docs ( https://www.apollographql.com/docs/react/data/mutations/#making-all-other-cache-updates ):
"If a mutation updates a single existing entity, Apollo Client can automatically update that entity's value in its cache when the mutation returns. To do so, the mutation must return the id of the modified entity, along with the values of the fields that were modified. Conveniently, mutations do this by default in Apollo Client."

topLevelComment.author: Matt F.
topLevelComment.text:
People asking how to get good enough to build this by yourself, escaping tutorials, I'd say to add features the course/tutorial didn't cover. I only watched about 1 minute of this video, but just from the app demo that I've seen, consider adding the following: 
* Email integration (forgot password, confirm account) 
* Profile View (user's can click on each others profiles and maybe "follow" them)
* Profile Edits (users can upload information about themselves: email, website, "about me", etc.) 
* Edit posts (users can delete their post, but not edit them. Add an "edit" feature.) 
* File uploads (allow users to upload images, maybe videos, etc.)
* Change the styling, make it your own

Try to make it a *real* project. Make it your own. This has helped me the most.

replies.author: San Nge
replies.text: It is because you do not try. You need to at least try after having enough ish understanding about the topic. Build an app of your interest and use Google and youtube when you get stuck. Try to create a design of the app before you even dive into coding. After doing them a couple of time, you will get comfortable writing those programs without evening googling. At least that is what I did, and it works everytime.

replies.author: Salim Regragui
replies.text: Advice that helped me through my journey. Never ever watch more than one tutorial for a specific technology or framework. Watch one tutorial and then do projects on your own. No one expects you to do them 100% on your own, if you're stuck search in stackoverflow, forums,...

replies.author: Toomas Kotkas
replies.text: Is it possible to build an app using some kind of provided 3rd party software? Probably. But it's going to look and work like 100000s other apps that were build from the same software by other people. If you want to create something new, you need to know the basics. First, you are dealing with people's private information and if it's not dealt properly it will be a financial or criminal disaster. Second, you want to build something new, that has never been build before and it's only possible if you know the purpose of every tool that you use. At the very least you need to know MVC (Model-View-Controller) framework .
